Evolutionary adaptation is related to time of arrival. Whitney and Gabler
26 reported 82 evolutionary changes in 38 species of plants and animals between their native and introduced ranges. Each trait considered was adapted in several species, showing that changes in invasive traits are relatively common. Additionally, some changes occurred within 20Â years, a much shorter time-span than F. limosus, A. leptodactylus and P. clarkii are present in the Netherlands. Such rapid evolutionary change could be caused by adaptive phenotypic plasticity, where invasive populations experience directional selection resulting in enhanced fitness
66 . Niche shifts observed in crayfish regarding climate adaptation
34 might be an example of this process and could have contributed to the current invasive success of F. limosus and P. clarkii.
